channel.title: Geometry on Mr. Eric
channel.description: Recent content in Geometry on Mr. Eric

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XX. -- THEOREM.
item.description: The sum of any two sides (BA, AC) of a triangle (ABC) is greater than the third.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIX. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If one angle (B) of a triangle (ABC) be greater than another angle (C), the side (AC) which it opposite to the greater angle is greater than the side (AB) which is opposite to the less.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If in any triangle (ABC) one side (AC) be greater than another (AB), the angle opposite to the greater side is greater than the angle opposite to the less.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: Any two angles (B, C) of a triangle (ABC) are together less than two right angles.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVI. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If any side (BC) of a triangle (ABC) be produced, the exterior angle (ACD) is greater than either of the interior non-adjacent angles.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If Two right lines (AB, CD) intersect one another, the opposite angles are equal (CEA=DEB, and BEC=AED)

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIV. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If at a point (B) in a right line (BA) two other right lines (CB, BD) on opposite sides make the adjacent angles (CBA, ABD) together equal to two right angles, these two right lines form one continuous line.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: The adjacent angles (ABC, ABD) which one right lines (AB) standing on another (CD) makes with it are either both right angles, or their sum is equal to two right angles.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XII. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To draw a perpendicular to a given indefinite right line (AB) from a given point (C) without it.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. XI. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: From a given point (C) in a given right line (AB) to draw a right line perpendicular to the given line.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. X. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To bisect a given finite right line (AB).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. IX. -- PROBLEM.
item.description: To bisect a given rectilineal angle (BAC).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. VIII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two sides (AB, AC) of one respectively equal to two sides…

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. VII. -- THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangles (ACB, ADB) on the same base (AB) and on the same side of it have one …

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. VI. – THEOREM.
item.description: If two angles (B, C) of a triangle be equal, the sides (AC, AB) opposite to them are also equal.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. V. – THEOREM.
item.description: The angles (ABC, ACB) at the base (BC) of an isosceles triangle are equal to one another…

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. IV. – THEOREM.
item.description: If two triangle (BAC, EDF) have two sides (BA, AC) of one equal respectively to two sides…

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. III. – PROBLEM.
item.description: From the greater (AB) of two given right lines to cut off a part equal to (C) the less.

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. II. – PROBLEM.
item.description: From a given point (A) to draw a right line equal to a given finite right line (BC).

item.title: Euclid Book I PROP. I. – PROBLEM.
item.description: On a given finite right line (AB) to construct an equilateral triangl.
